Authors:
Perinçek Seçkinozan ŞEKER, Ahmet Yesari Selçuk, Engin
Selvi, Mehmet Baran, Saffet Teber, Gökçe Ali Keleş, Haluk Kefelioğlu,
Coskun Tez, Osman İbiş
Title:
Complete mitochondrial genomes of Chionomys roberti and
Chionomys nivalis (Mammalia: Rodentia) from Turkey, with the taxonomic
implications
Abstract:
The complete mitochondrial DNA (mitogenome) sequences of
Chionomys nivalis and C. roberti were firstly presented as reference
mitogenomes by the current study using Long-Range PCR and
Next-Generation Sequencing. The structure and organization of the
circular mitogenomes were similar for each species. Each mitogenome
included 22 tRNA genes, 2 rRNA genes, 13 protein-coding genes (PCGs), a
control region (D-loop), and an origin of the light-strand region (OL),
with the mitogenome lengths of 16.293 for C. nivalis and 16.300 for C.
roberti. Phylogenetic analyses based on whole mitogenomes sequences
allowed us to see better the relative position of the Chionomys within
Arvicolinae. According to this, Chionomys was in a close phylogenetic
relationship with Microtus rather than Arvicola. Contrary to
expectations, the cytochrome b sequences based analyses pointed out the
more complex phylogenetic relationships among Chionomys species may be.
Additionally, the presence of at least 10 genetic lineages within C.
nivalis was approved. Among them, the Central Taurus lineage genetically
was the most distant lineage from others. On the other hand, Turkish C.
roberti specimens were clustered with the Transcaucasian specimens
(Datvisi- Georgia and Alania-North Ossetia-Russia) splitting from other
GenBank specimens of Russia and Georgia. Divergence time analyses
demonstrated that the first appearance of Arvicolinae dates back to the
Early Pliocene (4.97 mya, 95% HPD: 4.05-5.81, BPP: 1), compatible with
the past findings. Also, it was detected that the split of Arvicola /
Chionomys + Microtus took place at the beginning of the Quaternary
period (2.35 mya, 95% HPD: 1.96-2.75, BPP: 0.99). This corresponded to
the Early Pleistocene divergence (approximately 2.4 mya) of these three
genera suggested by the fossil record. In addition to this, molecular
dating analyses demonstrated that the divergence between C. nivalis and
C. roberti occurred in the Middle Pleistocene (1.06 mya, 95% HPD:
0.88-1.25, BPP: 1). There is no doubt that further studies employing
additional markers are needed in order to definite judgements on the
taxonomy and evolution of Chionomys.
